instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with liquid damage mainly in <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> area. Before working on the board it did get 20V and appeared to be booting. After replacing surrounding affected components board got stuck at 5v. All LDO voltages present.  Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> to rule out but no change.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates around .500v-.900v <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> however it appears everywhere else on the board 3.3V

What could be causing 3.3v to flucuate only on <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>? No short to ground and already replaced <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Broken trace; run a wire to other convenient <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: When the wire is ran the usb amp meter turns on and off every few seconds

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: More damage in that area; maybe some trace/pad under <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
ran wire to different spot and meter is not boot looping anymore. solid 3.4V on <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> now but still only 5V. 

Any specific pads that should be checked under <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
The one for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
Be aware, the opposite side could be affected by the heat.
You should reball/change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and check its surrounding components and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> continuity is good to both CD3215s

Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> as well to rule out. Checked all surrounding components and traces thoroughly, everything looks good.Both CD3215S LDO rails measure good.

Noticed <SIGNAL>UPC_XB_GATE1</SIGNAL> is only 11V AND <SIGNAL>UPC_GATE2</SIGNAL> only 6.5V

What should ve checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Don't waste time measuring gate pin of any MOSFET.

Something happened when you work on the board, if was switching to 20V before.
Heat affected some corroded area, or BGA chip.
Inspect <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> solders and traces.

Do you get now 1V1 LDO on the powered port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> solders and traces look fine, they were not affected by the spill.

1V1 LDO  missing on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> even though both CD3215s were replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Replaced both CD3215S once again to rule out the chip being bad or fake by using reballed untouched ones from donar.

Still 0v on 1V1 LDO  <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

1v1LDO is however present on UB400 and UB300.

Found other post about this issue to check voltage on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>. 5V is  present.

What else could be causing this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 1V1 LDO appears on the other ports?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Replaced both CD3215S once again to rule out the chip being bad or fake by using reballed untouched ones from donar.

Still 0v on 1V1 LDO  <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

1v1LDO is however present on UB400 and UB300.

Found other post about this issue to check voltage on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>. 5V is  present.

What else could be causing this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Something happened when you've worked on that area.
Possibly internal trace damaged; liquid spill could got between copper layers.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: anything else worth trying or checking or does it sound unrepairable at this point??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Not too much  :(,
Some traces can't be checked, as no test points available (BGA --> BGA).
